Award.AwardTitle: Influence of Small Molecule Additives on Gemini Dicarboxylate Lyotropic Liquid Crystal Structure and Stability
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Mahesh Mahanthappa of the University of Wisconsin-Madison is studying how small molecule surfactants, in which a water-soluble headgroup is attached to a water-insoluble tail, self-assemble in water. At high surfactant concentrations in water, these molecules spontaneously form a variety of structurally periodic soft materials known as liquid crystals. Certain liquid crystal structures are particularly useful in practical technical applications, yet these structures are difficult to access and their properties are limited. This project addresses these problems by investigating how adding salts and oils to water/surfactant mixtures enables the formation of these useful liquid crystals. A subset of the resulting materials may find long term application in fields such as therapeutic drug delivery. Another aspect of this project focuses on converting these liquid crystals into useful polymer membranes for energy efficient separations of complex chemical mixtures and for the generation and use of renewable fuels derived from solar energy. The broader impacts of this work include mentoring graduate and undergraduate students in research projects at the boundary between fundamental science and technological innovation, which will is expected to lead to useful materials for future healthcare and renewable energy applications.

This project investigates how small molecule additives control the water concentration-dependent self-assembly of gemini ("twin tail") dicarboxylate surfactants to form lyotropic liquid crystals (LLCs). A special emphasis in this project is placed on identifying methods for stabilizing network phase LLCs with interwoven, periodic, and percolating 3D-networks of aqueous and hydrophobic domains. The influence of various hydrophilic, hydrophobic, and amphiphilic molecular additives on LLC structure formation and stability are being evaluated by polarized light microscopy and temperature-dependent X-ray scattering. These studies are informing the development of mixtures of reactive surfactants and molecular additives that spontaneously form network phase LLCs for subsequent polymerization into functional, nanoporous polymer membranes. Professor Mahanthappa is translating related research results into public outreach demonstrations that showcase the utility of simple "soaps" in hydraulic fracturing applications ("fracking") for oil and gas recovery, to engage the public in broader discussions of energy harvesting technologies and global energy demands.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Soaps" are molecules that derive from linking a hydrophilic ("water loving") headgroup to a hydrophobic ("water hating"), oily hydrocarbon tail. Since "like dissolves like," addition of water to these amphiphilic molecules drives them to aggregate into nanometer-length scale structures such that the hydrophilic headgroup is surrounded by water and the hydrophobic tail is sequestered to minimize unfavorable water/oil contacts. While dilute solutions of soaps are typically used as cleaning agents and are integral ingredients in personal care and cosmetics formulations, their concentrated dispersions form 3D periodic packings of spherical aggregates known as micelles as well as 3D periodic bicontinuous networks. Both of these so-called 3D lyotropic liquid crystal (LLC) nanostructures form the basis of current and prospective technologies, which include templates for mesoporous inorganic materials for energy conversion devices (e.g., batteries and fuel cells) and petrochemical refining, platforms for protein structure determination in drug discovery, and as materials for delivery of human therapeutics. 

     This project focused on the water-induced self-assembly behaviors of gemini ("twin tail and twin head") surfactants in the presence of various additives. We sought to understand how additives impact the ability of hydrated gemini dicarboxylate surfactants to form 3D network LLCs, which are difficult to access and to tailor for specific applications. In one research thrust, we studied the self-assembly properties of a series of new gemini surfactants in the presence of water and a hydrocarbon oil. In another major research thrust, we analyzed how mixtures of twin tail gemini and single tail surfactants synergistically self-assemble into network LLCs. These systematic studies revealed new insights into the formation of both LLC 3D networks and 3D sphere packings, which will enable chemical engineers, materials scientists, and biologists to capitalize on their unique properties in future applications.

     Intellectual Merit: Although the impacts of small molecule additives (e.g., salts and alkanes) on the aggregation of single-tail amphiphiles in aqueous media are well-understood, few studies address the effects of such additives on the self-assembly behaviors of structurally complex amphiphiles. Since gemini dicarboxylate surfactants exhibit an unusual propensity to form 3D network LLCs in water, we sought to understand how additives impact their structures and stabilities. Using a cross-disciplinary combination of synthetic chemistry and materials characterization techniques, we discovered how gemini surfactant structures subtly direct aqueous LLC self-assembly in the presence of hydrocarbon oils to form either 3D networks of 3D spherical micelle packings. These studies led to the discovery of two newLLC structures. We also identified specific gemini surfactant additives that synergistically direct the self-assembly of single-tail alkyl carboxylate amphiphiles into 3D network LLCs. Fundamental insights derived from this project into the stabilization of bicontinuous and droplet microemulsions may significantly impact the development of future liquid crystal materials for drug delivery, protein structure determination, and separation membranes for water purification. Research findings have been disseminated to academic and industrial scientists through invited conference presentations, industrial outreach through presentations at chemical industry research centers and industrial consortium meetings, and through five (5) published and two (2) submitted peer-reviewed journal publications.

     Broader Impacts: This project significantly trained five (5) graduate students (including one underrepresented minority and two women) and three (3) undergraduate students (including one woman) in: (a) collaborative and cross-disciplinary research involving synthetic, physical organic, and materials chemistry, (b) effective written and verbal communication of scientific research results through peer-reviewed publications and international conference presentations, and (c) modern standards for laboratory safety. Project personnel were also involved in efforts to broaden participation of traditionally under-represented students in science, technology, and mathematics (STEM) professions, including a student research presentation at a Hispanic serving institution, and student organization of and participation in STEM outreach events to convey excitement about learning and doing scientific research to under-represented middle school students in the cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul. Through studies situated at the interface between fundamental science and emerging technologies, this project has broadened participation of traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM professions while contributing new research insights that will inform next-generation applications of liquid crystal materials in water, energy, and healthcare applications.


Last Modified: 11/22/2019
Modified by: Mahesh K Mahanthappa

Since "like dissolves like," addition of water to these amphiphilic molecules drives them to aggregate into nanometer-length scale structures such that the hydrophilic headgroup is surrounded by water and the hydrophobic tail is sequestered to minimize unfavorable water/oil contacts. Both of these so-called 3D lyotropic liquid crystal (LLC) nanostructures form the basis of current and prospective technologies, which include templates for mesoporous inorganic materials for energy conversion devices (e.g., batteries and fuel cells) and petrochemical refining, platforms for protein structure determination in drug discovery, and as materials for delivery of human therapeutics.
